yoruba: Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu.
gold: A person only newly acquainted with wealth; he has a son and names him Ọlaniyọnu.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu" translates to English as: "The future is unpredictable; it gives birth to a child and names it 'Wealth is Worrisome.'" This proverb suggests that the future is uncertain and can bring unexpected challenges or responsibilities, even when it seems promising.

yoruba: Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù.
gold: The measure of the rat is the measure of the nest; a robin does not live on a cushion.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù" can be translated into English as: "The size of the rat determines the size of the trap; a wise person does not act recklessly." This proverb emphasizes the importance of being cautious and acting according to the situation.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ tó fi ara wé igún, ẹ̀hìn àdìrò ní ńsùn.
gold: Whatever bird emulates the vulture will find itself behind the cooking hearth.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹyẹ tó fi ara wé igún, ẹ̀hìn àdìrò ní ńsùn" translates to "The bird that compares itself to a vulture sleeps behind the kitchen" in English. This proverb suggests that one should not compare themselves to others who are in a different situation or have different capabilities, as it may lead to unfavorable outcomes.

yoruba: Àwúrèbeé ní òún lè yẹ̀nà; ta ní jẹ́ tọ ọ̀nà àwúrèbe?
gold: Àwúrebe says it can make a path; who would wish to follow a path it makes?
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àwúrèbeé ní òún lè yẹ̀nà; ta ní jẹ́ tọ ọ̀nà àwúrèbe?" can be translated into English as: "The trickster claims to know the way; who would dare follow the path of a trickster?" This proverb suggests skepticism about following someone who is known for being deceitful or unreliable.

yoruba: Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ńtẹ́.
gold: Save face with members of your household and save face with complete strangers, such a person loses face with himself/herself.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ńtẹ́" translates to English as: "Do not rely on the host, do not rely on the guest; it is one's own hand that one should rely on." This proverb emphasizes the importance of self-reliance and not depending too much on others.

yoruba: Eégún ju eégún; òrìṣá ju òrìṣà; Pààká lé oníṣàngó wọ̀gbẹ́.
gold: Some masqueraders are greater than others; some gods are greater than others; the masquerader Pààká chases the Ṣàngó worshipper into the bush.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Eégún ju eégún; òrìṣá ju òrìṣà; Pààká lé oníṣàngó wọ̀gbẹ́" can be translated into English as: "Masquerades surpass masquerades; deities surpass deities; the Pààká (a type of masquerade) outshines the Sango worshipper." 

This proverb suggests that in any category or group, there are always individuals or entities that stand out or excel beyond others.

yoruba: “Mo yó” ńjẹ́ “mo yó,” “mo kọ̀” ńjẹ́ “mo kọ̀”; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni.
gold: “I am full” means “I am full”; “I decline” means “I decline”; eating with abandon, that is the father of all greediness.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "“Mo yó” ńjẹ́ “mo yó,” “mo kọ̀” ńjẹ́ “mo kọ̀”; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni." can be translated into English as: "“I am full” means “I am full,” “I am not full” means “I am not full”; eating secretly is the behavior of a greedy elder." 

This proverb highlights the importance of honesty and transparency, especially in the context of contentment and satisfaction. It suggests that trying to hide one's true state or intentions, particularly when it comes to greed, is not a commendable trait.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà kì í wẹwọ́ tán kó ní òun ó jẹ si.
gold: An elder does not wash his hand and then decide to eat more.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àgbàlagbà kì í wẹwọ́ tán kó ní òun ó jẹ si" translates to "An elder does not finish eating and say they will eat more" in English. This proverb emphasizes the wisdom and contentment often associated with elders, suggesting that they know when to stop or have enough.

yoruba: Ẹni à bá tà ká fowó-o rẹ̀ ra àdá: ó ní ìyà àdá ńjẹ òun.
gold: A person who should be sold for money to purchase a machete bemoans his lack of a machete.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹni à bá tà ká fowó-o rẹ̀ ra àdá: ó ní ìyà àdá ńjẹ òun" translates to English as: "The person we sell and use the money to buy a machete says the machete is causing them suffering." This proverb suggests that someone is complaining about a situation or consequence that they themselves have contributed to or brought upon themselves.

yoruba: Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú.
gold: Rather than prostrate oneself in homage or obeisance to a Hausa person, one should rather die.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú" translates to "Instead of bowing down to Gàm̀bàrí, we would rather endure and die." This proverb emphasizes the value of maintaining one's dignity and integrity, even in the face of hardship or adversity, rather than submitting to someone perceived as unworthy or oppressive.

yoruba: À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú.
gold: Feeding-without-leaving kills the Tullberg's rat; feeding-without-departing kills the spotted grass mouse; feeding-without-departing kills the máláàjú rat.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú" can be translated into English as: "Inability to remove oneself from a situation is what kills the monkey; inability to remove oneself is what kills the fly; inability to remove oneself is what kills the antelope." This proverb highlights the importance of knowing when to leave a situation to avoid negative consequences.

yoruba: A kì í fi ìka ro etí, ká fi ro imú, ká wá tún fi ta ehín.
gold: One does not use one's finger to clean one's ear passages, use it to pick one's nose, and then use it to pick one's teeth.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A kì í fi ìka ro etí, ká fi ro imú, ká wá tún fi ta ehín" translates to English as "One does not use a finger to measure the ear, then use it to measure the nose, and then use it to count the teeth." This proverb suggests that it is inappropriate or ineffective to use the same approach or method for different situations or tasks, as each requires its own specific consideration or tool.

yoruba: Ṣàkì ńṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ńṣe bí ẹran.
gold: The tripe presents itself as fat; the bone presents itself as meat.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ṣàkì ńṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ńṣe bí ẹran" translates to "The sack behaves like a load, the bone behaves like meat" in English. This proverb suggests that appearances can be deceiving, and things are not always what they seem.

yoruba: Ọ̀yájú-u baálé ní ńpàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà.
gold: It is a reckless home owner who is met with alarms when he ventures outside.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ọ̀yájú-u baálé ní ńpàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà" translates to "A disrespectful head of the household encounters disgrace on the way" in English. This proverb suggests that a leader or person in authority who lacks respect or humility will eventually face shame or dishonor.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà tí ò kí Ààrẹ ńfi okùn sin ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: An elder who does not greet the Ààrẹ tries a “hanging” rope for size.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àgbàlagbà tí ò kí Ààrẹ ńfi okùn sin ara-a rẹ̀" translates to English as "An elder who does not greet the president is digging his own grave." This proverb suggests that showing respect to those in authority or higher positions is important, and failing to do so can lead to negative consequences for oneself.

yoruba: Àì-lápá làdá ò mú; bí a bá lápá, ọmọ owú to-o gégi.
gold: It is a deficiency of biceps that blunts the machete; if one has strong biceps one can cut trees with a cudgel.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àì-lápá làdá ò mú; bí a bá lápá, ọmọ owú to-o gégi" can be translated into English as: "Without effort, the axe cannot cut; if we exert effort, even a cotton child can cut wood." This proverb emphasizes the importance of effort and hard work in achieving results, suggesting that with determination and effort, even seemingly difficult tasks can be accomplished.

yoruba: Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé.
gold: Wherever one situates the body, there it inhabits.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé" translates to "Where one places oneself is where one will find comfort" in English. This proverb suggests that the choices we make about where we position ourselves in life determine our comfort and well-being.

yoruba: Bí ìlàrí bá fẹ́ tẹ́, a ní kí lọba ó ṣe?
gold: When a courtier seeks disgrace, he asks, “What can the king do?”
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí ìlàrí bá fẹ́ tẹ́, a ní kí lọba ó ṣe?" translates to English as "If the royal messenger wants to fail, what can the king do?" This proverb suggests that when someone in a position of responsibility or trust decides to fail or not fulfill their duties, there is little that those in higher authority can do to prevent it. It highlights the importance of personal responsibility and integrity.

yoruba: Àfi ohun tí a kì í tà lọ́jà lẹrú kì í jẹ.
gold: The only thing a slave cannot eat is something not available in the market.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àfi ohun tí a kì í tà lọ́jà lẹrú kì í jẹ" translates to English as "A slave does not eat what is not sold in the market." This proverb suggests that one should not indulge in or take advantage of things that are not meant for them or that are not available to them. It emphasizes the importance of knowing one's place and respecting boundaries.

yoruba: Àṣá kì í rà kádìẹ gbé kòkòrò dání.
gold: When a kite hovers, a chicken does not hang on to an insect.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àṣá kì í rà kádìẹ gbé kòkòrò dání" translates to "The hawk does not carry a chick while holding an insect." This proverb suggests that one cannot handle two tasks or responsibilities at the same time effectively, emphasizing the importance of focusing on one thing at a time.

yoruba: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.
gold: Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, “I do not like it, and I will not accept it” is how the imbecile ends the discussion.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn" translates to English as: "After discussing strategies and wisdom, it is 'I don't want, I won't accept' that a fool uses to end a matter." This proverb suggests that a foolish person often dismisses wise counsel or solutions, choosing instead to reject them outright.

yoruba: Ẹni tí a fẹ́ yàtọ̀ sí ẹni tó ní kò sí irú òun.
gold: A person one loves is different from a person who says there is no one like him/herself.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹni tí a fẹ́ yàtọ̀ sí ẹni tó ní kò sí irú òun" translates to English as "The person we love is different from the one who claims there is no one like them." This proverb suggests that the qualities we value in someone we love may not necessarily align with self-perceived uniqueness or superiority.

yoruba: Àgùnbánirọ̀ ní ńfojúdini.
gold: It is the person taller than another who shows no respect for the other.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àgùnbánirọ̀ ní ńfojúdini" can be translated into English as "A person who is deceitful will eventually be exposed." This proverb suggests that deceitful actions or intentions will ultimately come to light.

yoruba: Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A vine as thick as a palm-tree trunk will not stop an elephant; whatever vine attempts to stop an elephant from going to Alọ will go with the elephant instead.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ńlọ" can be translated into English as: "A rope that is long enough to tie a palm tree is not necessarily strong enough to restrain a horse; a rope that can restrain a horse is the one that is strong and durable." 

This proverb emphasizes the idea that suitability and strength are not just about size or length, but about the right qualities for the task at hand.

yoruba: Bí a bá ńgúnyán, kòmẹsẹ̀ á yọ.
gold: If one prepares pounded yams, the uninvited should depart.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí a bá ńgúnyán, kòmẹsẹ̀ á yọ" translates to "When pounding yam, the toes must get smeared." This proverb suggests that when you are involved in a task, especially one that is messy or challenging, it is inevitable that you will get involved or affected by it in some way.

yoruba: Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ńja epo sáyà.
gold: A child new to eating stews: he shows himself by dripping palm-oil on his chest.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ńja epo sáyà" translates to "A child who has never tasted soup is scooping oil into their pocket" in English. This proverb is often used to describe someone who is inexperienced or unfamiliar with something but is acting in a way that shows a lack of understanding or appreciation.

yoruba: Kì í dọwọ́-ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ.
gold: Responsibility does not devolve on the father only for him to say it is his son's duty.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Kì í dọwọ́-ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ" translates to "A father's hand does not become a child's hand" in English. This proverb suggests that the responsibilities, roles, or characteristics of a father cannot simply be transferred to a child. It emphasizes the distinction between generations and the unique roles each person plays.

yoruba: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé.
gold: It is fitting for everybody to bargain to reduce the cost of dyeing clothes, but not the bed wetter.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé" translates to English as "It is appropriate for everyone to show some restraint in mourning, but not for the one who has suffered the loss." This proverb suggests that while it is important for people to express sympathy and support, the depth of grief is most profound for the person directly affected by the loss.

yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ ọjọ́ kan ò tán bọ̀rọ̀.
gold: The disgrace one incurs in one day does not disappear that soon.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ìbàjẹ́ ọjọ́ kan ò tán bọ̀rọ̀" translates to "The damage of one day does not ruin a lifetime" in English. This proverb suggests that a single setback or mistake does not determine one's entire future or life.

yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ńpìtàn ká tó jogún, ká mọ̀ pé ogún ibẹ̀ ò kanni.
gold: Where one must recite genealogies in order to establish one's claim to inheritance, one should know that one really has no claim to patrimony there.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ibi tí a ti ńpìtàn ká tó jogún, ká mọ̀ pé ogún ibẹ̀ ò kanni" translates to English as: "Where stories are being told before inheritance, it is important to know that the inheritance is not significant." This proverb suggests that when there is a lot of discussion or storytelling before receiving an inheritance, it might indicate that the inheritance itself is not substantial or valuable.

yoruba: Bí baálẹ̀-ẹ́ bá ńtàkìtì, òrógi là ḿbá ẹmẹsẹ̀.
gold: If the chief is turning somersaults, the messenger should be found standing erect.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí baálẹ̀-ẹ́ bá ńtàkìtì, òrógi là ḿbá ẹmẹsẹ̀" can be translated into English as: "If the head of the household is struggling, the junior ones should carry firewood." This proverb suggests that when a leader or someone in charge is facing difficulties, it is important for others, especially subordinates or younger ones, to step up and support by taking on responsibilities.

yoruba: Afínjú wọ ọjà ó rìn gbẹndẹ́kẹ ọ̀bún wọ ọjà ó rìn ṣùẹ̀ṣùẹ̀; ọ̀bùn ní ó ru ẹrù afínjú relé.
gold: The fashionable person enters the market and walks in a leisurely manner; the filthy person enters the market and walks in a sluggish manner; it is the filthy person that will carry the fashionable person's load to the house for him or her.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Afínjú wọ ọjà ó rìn gbẹndẹ́kẹ ọ̀bún wọ ọjà ó rìn ṣùẹ̀ṣùẹ̀; ọ̀bùn ní ó ru ẹrù afínjú relé" can be translated into English as: "The dandy walks briskly in the market, while the slovenly person walks sluggishly; yet it is the slovenly person who helps carry the dandy's load home." 

This proverb highlights the idea that appearances can be deceiving, and those who may seem less capable or impressive can often be the ones who provide real support or assistance.

yoruba: Aáyán ati eèràá ṣígun, wọ́n ní àwọ́n ńlọ mú adìẹ àlọ la rí, a ò rábọ̀.
gold: Cockroach and ant make ready for war and say they are off to capture chicken; we see their departure, but not their return.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Aáyán ati eèràá ṣígun, wọ́n ní àwọ́n ńlọ mú adìẹ àlọ la rí, a ò rábọ̀" can be translated into English as: "The maggot and the ant are digging, they claim they are going to catch a runaway chicken, but we haven't seen the evidence." This proverb suggests skepticism about someone's claims or intentions, especially when there is no evidence to support them.

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ò mẹ̀yẹ.
gold: A pig does not know what is becoming.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹlẹdẹ ò mẹyẹ" translates to "The pig is not praiseworthy" in English. This proverb is often used to convey the idea that certain behaviors or characteristics are inherently unworthy of praise or admiration, regardless of the context.

yoruba: Ẹ̀wọ̀n tó tó ọ̀pẹ ò tó-ó dá erin dúró; ìtàkùn tó ní kí erin má ròkè ọ̀dàn, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A chain as thick as a palm-tree cannot stop an elephant; the vine that proposes to stop the elephant from going to the grassland will go with the elephant.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ẹ̀wọ̀n tó tó ọ̀pẹ ò tó-ó dá erin dúró; ìtàkùn tó ní kí erin má ròkè ọ̀dàn, tòun terin ní ńlọ" can be translated into English as: "The rope that is strong enough to tie a palm tree is not strong enough to stop an elephant; the tether that tells the elephant not to climb the savannah hill, the elephant says it is going there." 

This proverb suggests that some challenges or obstacles are not sufficient to deter someone or something determined to pursue their path. It highlights the idea of resilience and determination in the face of limitations.

yoruba: Àfòpiná tó ní òun ó pa fìtílà, ara ẹ̀ ni yó pa.
gold: The moth that attempts to kill (put out) the oil lamp will kill itself.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àfòpiná tó ní òun ó pa fìtílà, ara ẹ̀ ni yó pa" translates to "The extinguisher that says it will put out the lamp will extinguish itself." This proverb suggests that someone who seeks to harm others may end up harming themselves instead.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà akàn tó kó sí garawa yègèdè, ojú tì í.
gold: The elderly crab that enters into a bucket; it is thoroughly disgraced.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àgbàlagbà akàn tó kó sí garawa yègèdè, ojú tì í" can be translated into English as: "An old crab that is put into a wide container feels ashamed." This proverb suggests that someone who is experienced or mature may feel embarrassed or out of place when they find themselves in a situation that exposes their limitations or inadequacies.

yoruba: A pè ọ́ lọ́mọ erín-màgbọn ò ńyọ̀; ìwọ pàápàá ló mì í?
gold: You are described as the child of the elephant that swallows coconuts, and you rejoice; are you the one who swallows coconuts?
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "A pè ọ́ lọ́mọ erín-màgbọn ò ńyọ̀; ìwọ pàápàá ló mì í?" can be translated into English as: "We called you the child of a laughing hyena, and you are smiling; are you the one we are referring to?" 

This proverb is often used to caution someone who is reacting to a statement or situation that may not necessarily be about them, suggesting that they might be revealing their own guilt or involvement.

yoruba: Olówó ní ḿbá ọlọ́rọ̀-ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ḿbá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré.
gold: It is a rich person that keeps company with a wealthy person; only people of equal standing play together.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Olówó ní ḿbá ọlọ́rọ̀-ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ḿbá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré" translates to English as "The wealthy walk with the rich; peers play with peers." This proverb suggests that people tend to associate with others who are similar to them in status or circumstances.

yoruba: Kí ẹrú mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú; kí ìwọ̀fà mọ ara ẹ̀ níwọ̀fà; kí ọmọlúwàbí mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú Ọlọ́run ọba.
gold: Let the slave know him/herself as a slave; let the pawn know him/herself as a pawn; let the well born person know him/herself as the child of God.
gen: The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "Let the servant know themselves as a servant; let the apprentice know themselves as an apprentice; let a person of good character know themselves as a servant of God, the King."

yoruba: A kì í gbọ́n ju ẹni tí a máa dÍfá fún.
gold: One cannot be wiser than the person for whom one will consult the Ifá oracle.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A kì í gbọ́n ju ẹni tí a máa dÍfá fún" translates to "One cannot be wiser than the person for whom divination is being performed" in English. This proverb suggests that the person seeking guidance or insight (through divination, in this context) is the one who ultimately benefits from the wisdom or knowledge being sought.

yoruba: Kí ni wọ́n ti ńṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ńjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.
gold: What use do the people of Ilorin have for Ahmadu? Even goats are so named.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Kí ni wọ́n ti ńṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ńjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀." translates to English as "What is Àmọdù doing in Ilorin? A goat is eating there." This proverb is often used to imply that someone is in a place or situation for a specific reason or benefit, often one that is obvious or self-serving.

yoruba: A-dá-má-lè-ṣe àdàbà tí ńdún bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀.
gold: Start-something-it-cannot-finish dove that makes bombastic noises.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A-dá-má-lè-ṣe àdàbà tí ńdún bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀" can be translated into English as "One who claims to be gentle like a dove but makes a lot of noise." This proverb is often used to describe someone who pretends to be calm and peaceful but is actually disruptive or troublesome.

yoruba: A-lu-dùndún kì í dárin.
gold: The dùndún player does not lead a song.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A-lu-dùndún kì í dárin" translates to "One who plays the dundun drum does not dance" in English. This proverb suggests that a person who is responsible for a particular task or role may not be able to participate in other activities simultaneously. It highlights the idea of focusing on one's responsibilities.

yoruba: Aláṣọ-kan kì í ná ànárẹ.
gold: A person who has only one set of clothing does not bargain until he is wet.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Aláṣọ-kan kì í ná ànárẹ" translates to "A person with only one cloth does not go near the fire" in English. This proverb suggests that one should avoid taking unnecessary risks, especially when they have limited resources or options.

yoruba: Ọjọ́ àgbà-á kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbà-á tẹ́.
gold: The day an elder dies is far better than the day an elder is disgraced.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ọjọ́ àgbà-á kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbà-á tẹ́" translates to "The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder falls into disgrace" in English. This proverb emphasizes the value of maintaining dignity and honor throughout one's life.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò lè rí omi inú àgbọn bù mu.
gold: A bird cannot get at the liquid inside a coconut to drink.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹyẹ ò lè rí omi inú àgbọn bù mu" translates to "A bird cannot drink the water inside a coconut" in English. This proverb suggests that some things are beyond one's reach or capability, no matter how much one desires them.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tán” lOrò-ó fi ńgbé ọkùnrin.
gold: “I know it all” is the reason for Orò's carrying a man away.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "“Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tán” lOrò-ó fi ńgbé ọkùnrin" translates to "The phrase 'I know it all' is what ruins a man" in English. This proverb warns against the dangers of arrogance and the assumption of knowing everything, which can lead to one's downfall.

yoruba: Nígbàtí à ńto ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si.
gold: When we were stacking the corn we did not stack some for the brown rat.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Nígbàtí à ńto ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si" translates to "When we are arranging the corn, we do not arrange the chaff with it" in English. This proverb suggests the importance of focusing on what is valuable and separating it from what is not.

yoruba: Àbúrò rẹ ńdáṣọ fún ọ, o ní o ò lo elékuru; ta ní ńlo alákàrà?
gold: Your junior brother (or sister) buys clothing for you, and you say you will not wear anything with bean-grits patterns; who has the right to opt for clothing with a bean-fritter patterns?
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Àbúrò rẹ ńdáṣọ fún ọ, o ní o ò lo elékuru; ta ní ńlo alákàrà?" can be translated into English as: "Your younger sibling is sewing clothes for you, and you say you don't wear rags; who then wears bean cakes?" 

This proverb highlights the idea of rejecting something valuable or beneficial due to a misunderstanding or undervaluation of its worth.

yoruba: Bí kò sí tọ̀bùn èèyàn, ta ni ìbá jí lówùúrọ̀ tí kò bọ́jú ṣáṣá?
gold: But for a person of filthy habits, who would wake in the morning and not wash his or her face clean?
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí kò sí tọ̀bùn èèyàn, ta ni ìbá jí lówùúrọ̀ tí kò bọ́jú ṣáṣá?" can be translated into English as: "If there were no good people, who would wake up in the morning without covering their face in shame?" This proverb emphasizes the importance of having good people in society, as they contribute to a sense of pride and integrity.

yoruba: Àpọ́nlé ni “İyá-a Káà”; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ.
gold: Calling a person “Mother of the Compound” is only a mark of respect; there is no mother in the compound who does not have a name.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àpọ́nlé ni “İyá-a Káà”; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ." translates to English as: "Respect is given to 'Mother of the Town'; there is no mother in the town without a name." This proverb emphasizes the importance of respect and recognition, suggesting that everyone has their own identity and deserves acknowledgment.

yoruba: Bí iná bá dun ọbẹ̀, a dá ọ̀rọ̀ sọ.
gold: If the fire gets at the stew, the stew will burst into speech.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí iná bá dun ọbẹ̀, a dá ọ̀rọ̀ sọ" translates to "When the stew is delicious, we find something to talk about" in English. This proverb suggests that when things are going well or are enjoyable, people are more inclined to engage in conversation or share stories.

yoruba: Àṣejù baba àṣetẹ́; ẹ̀tẹ́ ní ńgbẹ̀hìn àṣejù; àgbàlagbà tó wẹ̀wù àṣejù ẹ̀tẹ́ ni yó fi rí.
gold: Lack of moderation is the father of disgrace; disgrace comes of immoderation; a grown person who clothes himself in immoderation will find disgrace.
gen: The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "Excess is the father of inadequacy; inadequacy is the end result of excess; an elder who wears the garment of excess will end up with inadequacy."

yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ńtẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ńtini.
gold: It takes one day only for one to disgrace oneself; the shame is a daily affair.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ńtẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ńtini" translates to English as "We only have to pound yam once; every day the eyes face challenges." This proverb suggests that while some tasks are occasional, life presents daily challenges that must be faced regularly.

yoruba: A kì í dákẹ́ ká ṣìwí; a kì í wò sùn-ùn ká dáràn.
gold: One does not keep quiet and yet misspeak; one does not silently contemplate the world and yet get into trouble.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A kì í dákẹ́ ká ṣìwí; a kì í wò sùn-ùn ká dáràn" can be translated into English as: "One does not keep silent and still speak; one does not watch and still commit a crime." This proverb emphasizes the idea that certain actions or states are mutually exclusive, highlighting the importance of consistency between one's actions and intentions.

yoruba: Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n.
gold: Moderate your preening and strutting, beautiful woman of Ṣàpọ́n.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n" can be translated into English as "As you know, the bean seller at Ṣàpón." This proverb is often used to imply that something is common knowledge or that a situation is well understood by everyone involved.

yoruba: Gbogbo èèyàn ní ńsunkún-un Bánjọ; ṣùgbọ́n Bánjọ ò sunkún ara ẹ̀.
gold: Everybody laments Banjọ's fate, but Banjọ does not lament his own fate.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Gbogbo èèyàn ní ńsunkún-un Bánjọ; ṣùgbóṇ Bánjọ ò sunkún ara ẹ̀" translates to English as "Everyone cries for Bánjọ, but Bánjọ does not cry for himself." This proverb suggests that while others may feel sympathy or concern for someone, that person may not feel the same level of concern for their own situation.

yoruba: Idà ahun la fi ńpa ahun.
gold: It is with its own sword that one kills the tortoise.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Idà ahun la fi ńpa ahun" translates to "It is with the sword of a miser that a miser is killed" in English. This proverb suggests that the traits or actions of a person can lead to their own downfall, particularly when they are negative or harmful.

yoruba: Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́.
gold: A youth's food can enter the stomach of an elder; it is only a youth's ring that cannot slip unto an elder's finger.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́" translates to English as: "The food of a small child can enter an elder's stomach; but a small child's ring cannot fit an elder's finger." This proverb suggests that while some things meant for the young can be suitable for the old, not everything is interchangeable between generations.

yoruba: “Ẹ fà á wọlé” ló yẹ ẹlẹ́ṣin.
gold: “Lead it into the stable” is what becomes a horseman.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "“Ẹ fà á wọlé” ló yẹ ẹlẹ́ṣin" translates to "‘Pull it inside’ is appropriate for the horse rider" in English. This proverb suggests that those in control or in a position of responsibility should take charge and manage situations effectively.

yoruba: Ajá kì í lọ ságinjù lọ ṣọdẹ ẹkùn.
gold: A dog does not go into the wild to hunt a leopard.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ajá kì í lọ ságinjù lọ ṣọdẹ ẹkùn" translates to "A dog does not venture into the wilderness to hunt a leopard" in English. This proverb suggests that one should not take on challenges or tasks that are beyond their capacity or strength.

yoruba: Alátiṣe ní ḿmọ àtiṣe ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: The person who must settle his/her affair knows best how he/she plans to go about doing so.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Alátiṣe ní ḿmọ àtiṣe ara-a rẹ̀" translates to "The reformer knows how to reform himself" in English. This proverb emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and self-improvement, suggesting that those who seek to improve or correct others should first be capable of improving or correcting themselves.

yoruba: Àpárá ńlá, ìjà ní ńdà.
gold: Excessive ribbing unfailingly leads to a fight.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àpárá ńlá, ìjà ní ńdà" translates to "A big scar often leads to a fight" in English. This proverb suggests that significant issues or provocations can lead to conflicts or disputes.

yoruba: Òní, ẹtú jìnfìn, ọ̀la, ẹtú jìnfìn; ẹtu nìkan lẹran tó wà nígbó?
gold: Today, the antelope falls into the ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Òní, ẹtú jìnfìn, ọ̀la, ẹtú jìnfìn; ẹtu nìkan lẹran tó wà nígbó?" translates to English as: "Today, the duiker is elusive, tomorrow, the duiker is elusive; is the duiker the only animal in the forest?" 

This proverb is often used to express frustration or skepticism about repeated excuses or the idea that one thing is being overly focused on when there are other possibilities or options available.

yoruba: Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́.
gold: The wife who whips a relative of her husband is asking for stern rebuke.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́" translates to "A wife who beats another person's child is seeking to hear some words" in English. This proverb suggests that the wife is looking for a reaction or response, possibly indicating that her actions are intended to provoke a discussion or confrontation.

yoruba: “Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿbọ̀ ng ò rírú ẹ̀ rí”: olúwa ẹ̀-ẹ́ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni.
gold: “In all the days I have walked this earth I have never seen the like”: that person knows his place.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿbọ̀ ng ò rírú ẹ̀ rí”: olúwa ẹ̀-ẹ́ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni." can be translated into English as: "The day I will arrive, I have never seen its kind before: your master knows your limits." This proverb suggests that one should trust in their own abilities and understand that their challenges are unique, but manageable within their own capacity.

yoruba: Àì-kúkú-joye, ó sàn ju, “Ẹnuù mi ò ká ìlú” lọ.
gold: Not-assuming-the-position-of-ruler-at-all is far better than, “My word is not heeded by the people.”
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àì-kúkú-joye, ó sàn ju, “Ẹnuù mi ò ká ìlú” lọ" translates to English as "It is better not to accept a chieftaincy title than to say, 'I cannot handle the responsibilities of the community.'" This proverb emphasizes the importance of being prepared and capable before taking on significant responsibilities or roles.

yoruba: À-wín-ná-wó ò yẹni; à-gbà-bọ̀-ọ ṣòkòtò ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn; bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a dòrògí; ohun ẹni ní ńyẹni.
gold: Borrowing-money-to-spend does not speak well of one; borrowed trousers do not become a person; if it is not tight around the legs it is difficult to remove; it is one's thing that fits one.
gen: The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "Borrowed clothes do not befit one; borrowed trousers do not suit a person; if it does not trip you, it will make you stumble; what truly suits a person is what belongs to them." This proverb emphasizes the value of self-reliance and the idea that what truly fits or benefits a person is what they own or have earned themselves, rather than relying on what is borrowed or not genuinely theirs.

yoruba: Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olè-é kó òun?
gold: What did Dáàró own before he claimed he was robbed?
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olè-é kó òun?" can be translated into English as "What did Dáàró do before claiming that a thief robbed him?" This proverb is often used to suggest that one should consider their own actions or responsibilities before blaming others for their misfortunes.

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní “Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?”; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?
gold: A person says he has lost an unspecified amount of money, and you ask if the amount is five hundred cowries or eleven hundred cowries; which amount did you steal?
gen:
The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "The pig is going to the market, and it asks, 'Is it three hundred or six hundred?' Which one do you carry there?" 

This proverb is often used to highlight the absurdity of someone being involved in something without understanding the details or being prepared.

yoruba: Ojú kì í pọ́n baálé ilé kó fọwọ́ gbálẹ̀ ilé ẹ̀.
gold: A head of a household is never so hard up that he sweeps his compound with his bare hands.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ojú kì í pọ́n baálé ilé kó fọwọ́ gbálẹ̀ ilé ẹ̀" translates to English as "The head of a household does not become so blind that he uses his hands to feel his way around his own house." This proverb suggests that a person in a position of authority or familiarity should not become so incapacitated or unaware that they cannot manage their own responsibilities or environment.

yoruba: “Ẹ kú-ulé” ò yẹ ará ilé; “Ẹ kú atìbà” ò yẹni tí ńtàjò bọ̀; ẹni tí ò kí ẹni, “Kú atìbà”-á pàdánù “Ẹ kú-ulé.”
gold: “Greetings to you, house-bound ones” is improper for the house-bound to utter; “Welcome home” is not proper for the person arriving from a trip; whoever fails to give “welcome” to the person returning does himself or herself out of “greetings, house-bound.”
gen:
The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "Greeting 'Ẹ kú-ulé' is not necessary for those at home; 'Ẹ kú atìbà' is not needed for someone who is running for cover; the person who does not greet others with 'Kú atìbà' will miss out on 'Ẹ kú-ulé.'" 

This proverb emphasizes the importance of appropriate greetings and the idea that failing to acknowledge others in the right way can lead to missed opportunities for connection or support.

yoruba: Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú.
gold: What sort of meat is it, the likes of which one has never tasted? A toad comes upon one at the swamp and cowers in fright.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú" can be translated into English as: "What kind of meat have we not eaten before? When a frog meets you in the swamp, it becomes a serious matter." This proverb suggests that one may have encountered many challenges or experiences, but some situations can still be unexpectedly difficult or troublesome.

yoruba: A-binú-fùfù ní ńwá oúnjẹ fún a-binú-wẹ́rẹ́-wẹ́rẹ́.
gold: A volatile-tempered person secures food for a mild-tempered person.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A-binú-fùfù ní ńwá oúnjẹ fún a-binú-wẹ́rẹ́-wẹ́rẹ́" translates to "The one who is intensely angry seeks food for the one who is mildly angry." This proverb suggests that someone who is more intensely affected by a situation often takes action or makes efforts on behalf of someone who is less affected.

yoruba: Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n.
gold: The mud of the Ìjèṣà: it splashes on one and will not be washed off.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n" can be translated into English as: "The mud of Ìjèṣà, it splashes on you but does not stain." This proverb suggests that some situations or challenges may seem troublesome at first, but they do not have a lasting negative impact.

yoruba: Ta ní ńjẹun tájá ńjùrù?
gold: At whose dinner table is the dog wagging its tail?
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ta ní ńjẹun tájá ńjùrù?" can be translated into English as "Who is eating that the fish is getting spoiled?" This proverb is often used to question or criticize a situation where someone is neglecting their responsibilities or not taking care of something important, leading to waste or loss.

yoruba: Afínjú ní ńjẹ iwọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ńjẹ obì; màrí-màjẹ ní ńjẹ awùsá.
gold: It is a finicky person that eats iwọ;
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Afínjú ní ńjẹ iwọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ńjẹ obì; màrí-màjẹ ní ńjẹ awùsá" can be translated into English as: "The refined person eats the drumstick; the wise person eats the kola nut; the one who eats indiscriminately eats the chaff." This proverb highlights the idea that different people have different preferences and levels of discernment, often reflecting their character or wisdom.

yoruba: Bí a kò bá tó ìyà-á kọ̀ tí à ńkọ̀ ọ́, àjẹkún ìyà là ńjẹ.
gold: If one lacks the means to reject suffering and attempts to reject it, one's suffering simply multiplies.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí a kò bá tó ìyà-á kọ̀ tí à ńkọ̀ ọ́, àjẹkún ìyà là ńjẹ" translates to English as "If we do not properly measure the suffering we are enduring, we end up experiencing additional suffering." This proverb emphasizes the importance of addressing and managing challenges effectively to avoid exacerbating them.

yoruba: A kì í bọ òrìṣà lójú ọ̀fọ́n-ọ̀n; bó bá dalẹ́ a máa tú pẹpẹ.
gold: One does not sacrifice to a god in the presence of a house rat; otherwise, when night falls it invades the rafter shelves.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A kì í bọ òrìṣà lójú ọ̀fọ́n-ọ̀n; bó bá dalẹ́ a máa tú pẹpẹ" can be translated into English as: "One does not worship the deity with empty hands; if it gets late, one will spread a mat." This proverb emphasizes the importance of making proper offerings or preparations when seeking favor or assistance, suggesting that effort and sincerity are necessary in any endeavor.

yoruba: Ìwọ̀sí ní
gold: X
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ìwọ̀sí ní" can be translated into English as "It is the future that matters" or "The future is important." This proverb emphasizes the significance of looking forward and planning for what is to come.

yoruba: Àgbà tí kò lẹ́sẹ̀ nílẹ̀ a lọ́gbọ́n nínú.
gold: An elder that has no substance should have cunning.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Àgbà tí kò lẹ́sẹ̀ nílẹ̀ a lọ́gbọ́n nínú" translates to "An elder who is not physically strong is wise in mind" in English. This proverb emphasizes the value of wisdom and experience over physical strength, suggesting that even if an elder may not be physically robust, they possess valuable knowledge and insight.

yoruba: À ńjá ìbàǹtẹ́ ẹ̀ lẹ́hìn, ó ńjá tará iwájú.
gold: His loincloth is being stripped from behind, yet he is stripping those of the people ahead of him.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "À ńjá ìbàǹtẹ́ ẹ̀ lẹ́hìn, ó ńjá tará iwájú" translates to "While the back of your garment is being torn, the front is also being torn." This proverb suggests that when one problem is being addressed, another may arise, highlighting the complexity and interconnectedness of issues.

yoruba: Ẹ̀yá ló bí mi, ẹkùn ló wò mí dàgbà, ológìnní gbà mí tọ́; bí kò sẹ́ran lọ́bẹ̀ nkò jẹ.
gold: I was born of a monkey; I was raised by a leopard, I was adopted by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew I will not eat it.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ẹ̀yá ló bí mi, ẹkùn ló wò mí dàgbà, ológìnní gbà mí tọ́; bí kò sẹ́ran lọ́bẹ̀ nkò jẹ" can be translated into English as: "A tilapia gave birth to me, a leopard raised me, a lion trained me; if there is no meat in the soup, I won't eat." 

This proverb emphasizes the speaker's high standards and expectations, suggesting that they have been nurtured and trained by the best, and therefore, they will not settle for anything less than excellence.

yoruba: À-jẹ-tán, à-jẹ-ì-mọra, ká fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá jẹun ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.
gold: Eating-absolutely-everything, eating-with-abandon, eating with all ten fingers is unworthy of human beings.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "À-jẹ-tán, à-jẹ-ì-mọra, ká fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá jẹun ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn" translates to English as: "After eating, not being prepared, and using all ten fingers to eat is not appropriate for a person." This proverb suggests the importance of moderation, self-control, and preparedness in one's actions and behavior.

yoruba: Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún “Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn”?
gold: Darkness does not know who deserves deference; it consulted the oracle Ifá for “Who might you be?”
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún “Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn”?" can be translated into English as: "Darkness does not recognize a person; it consults the oracle for 'Who are you?'" This proverb suggests that in situations of uncertainty or obscurity, one's true identity or intentions may not be immediately apparent and may require deeper insight or understanding to discern.

yoruba: Bí ayá bá mojú ọkọ, alárìnnà a yẹsẹ̀.
gold: When the wife has got to know the husband, the marriage broker makes way.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí ayá bá mojú ọkọ, alárìnnà a yẹsẹ̀" translates to "When the wife and husband are in agreement, the mediator steps aside" in English. This means that when there is harmony or understanding between two parties, there is no need for a third party or mediator.

yoruba: Ẹni à ńgbé gẹ̀gẹ̀ ni yó ba ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ́.
gold: It is the person who is revered that will disgrace himself or herself.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹni à ńgbé gẹ̀gẹ̀ ni yó ba ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ" translates to "He who is being carried like a cripple will eventually harm himself" in English. This proverb suggests that relying too much on others or not taking responsibility for oneself can lead to negative consequences.

yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́.
gold: Spinach is never disgraced.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́" translates to "Haste does not yield results" or "Haste makes waste" in English. It conveys the idea that rushing through tasks often leads to mistakes or poor outcomes.

yoruba: Ẹní bá dẹ ojú-u rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ á rímú-u rẹ̀.
gold: Whoever gazes downwards with will see his or her nose.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ẹní bá dẹ ojú-u rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ á rímú-u rẹ̀" translates to "Whoever closes their eyes will cover their nose" in English. This proverb suggests that ignoring a problem or situation doesn't make it go away; it may lead to further complications.

yoruba: Onígẹ̀gẹ́ fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ dọ́pọ̀; onílẹ̀kẹ̀ ìbá gbowo, ko rọ́rùn fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ so.
gold: The person with goitre offers a ridiculously low price for beads; were the beads seller to accept her offer she would have no neck to string the beads around.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Onígẹ̀gẹ́ fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ dọ́pọ̀; onílẹ̀kẹ̀ ìbá gbowo, ko rọ́rùn fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ so" can be translated into English as: "The one who braids hair with beads is plentiful; if the bead owner were to charge, it wouldn't be easy to braid with beads." This proverb suggests that while many people may engage in an activity, it is not always easy or cheap to do so if the resources required were to be properly valued or charged for.

yoruba: Bí a bá ti mọ là ńdé; a-láì-lẹ́ṣin kì í dé wọ̀nwọ̀n.
gold: One arrives according to one's worth; a horseless person does not arrive with the noise of hoofs and stirrups.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí a bá ti mọ là ńdé; a-láì-lẹ́ṣin kì í dé wọ̀nwọ̀n" can be translated into English as: "We arrive as far as we know; one without a guide does not reach the destination." This proverb emphasizes the importance of knowledge and guidance in achieving one's goals.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀wọ̀n ara-à mi” kì í ṣẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ èébú.
gold: “I am jealous of my dignity” does not hurl insults at others.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "“Mo mọ̀wọ̀n ara-à mi” kì í ṣẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ èébú" translates to "Knowing one's limits does not lead to disgrace" in English. This proverb emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and understanding one's capabilities to avoid embarrassment or failure.

yoruba: A kì í bá ọba pàlà kí ọkọ́ ọba má ṣàn-ánni lẹ́sẹ̀.
gold: One does not share a farm boundary with a king without getting one's feet gashed by the king's hoe.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "A kì í bá ọba pàlà kí ọkọ́ ọba má ṣàn-ánni lẹ́sẹ̀" translates to English as "One does not walk with the king and have the king's horse trample on them." This proverb suggests that when you are in the company of someone powerful or influential, you are likely to receive some form of protection or benefit.

yoruba: Bí eegbọ́n bá ṣo ayínrín nímú, adìẹ kọ́ ni yó ja.
gold: If a tick clings to a fox's nose, it is not a chicken that will remove it.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Bí eegbọ́n bá ṣo ayínrín nímú, adìẹ kọ́ ni yó ja" translates to English as "If the elder blows sand into the nose, the chicken will not peck." This proverb suggests that when someone in a position of authority or respect acts inappropriately, it sets a precedent that discourages others from behaving correctly.

yoruba: À-sẹ́-kú làgbàlagbà ńsẹ́ ọ̀ràn.
gold: Denying-until-death is the way a venerable person denies a matter.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "À-sẹ́-kú làgbàlagbà ńsẹ́ ọ̀ràn" translates to "An elder handles matters with what is left undone" in English. This proverb suggests that wise or experienced individuals know how to manage or resolve issues by addressing what remains unfinished or by focusing on the essentials.

yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀ ò ti ibìkan mú ẹni; ìyà ò tibìkan jẹ èèyàn; bí o bá rìnrìn òṣì, bí o bá ojú ìṣẹ́ wọ̀lú, igbá-kúgbá ni wọn ó fi bu omi fún ẹ mu.
gold: Destitution does not attach to one at a particular place; suffering does not attack a person at a particular place; if one walks like a wretch into a town, if one looks like a loser when one enters a town, it is with a miserable calabash that the people will offer one water to drink.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb translates to English as: "Poverty does not hold anyone captive; suffering does not consume a person; if you walk the path of poverty and face hardship, you will be given water to drink in a calabash." 

This proverb suggests that despite facing difficulties or poverty, people will still find ways to support and help each other.

yoruba: Oòrùn, kó tìẹ wọ̀ ká má bàá Ọlọ́jọ́ wí.
gold: Sun, go set so one does not blame the owner of the day.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Oòrùn, kó tìẹ wọ̀ ká má bàá Ọlọ́jọ́ wí" translates to "Sun, set so that we do not speak ill of the Creator" in English. This proverb suggests that sometimes it is better to let things come to a natural end rather than forcing or complaining about them.

yoruba: Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi.
gold: I have become old and wise, but childish play has not ceased to appeal to me.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi" can be translated into English as: "I have grown old and experienced, yet the antics of a child are not beyond me." This proverb suggests that despite gaining wisdom and experience with age, one can still understand or relate to the behavior and actions of the younger generation.

yoruba: Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja.
gold: A person who has only  one wife does not form a circle for a fight.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja" translates to "A single woman does not settle a dispute" in English. This proverb suggests that resolving conflicts or disputes often requires the involvement or input of more than one person, emphasizing the importance of collaboration and collective effort.
